docs.lead_paragraph: Demos, talks and a paper-plate dinner buffet were the fare last Friday evening at the Computer Museum in Mountain View, Calif., and the subject was the high-tech future of health care. The gathering was hosted by FutureMed, a health-care program that is part of Singularity University, a networked organization dedicated to exploring how disruptive technologies can sweep across whole industries and society.

headline.main: The Future of High-Tech Health Care - and the Challenge

docs.abstract: New health-care technologies, like I.B.M.'s Watson computer, which is being developed as a smart assistant for physicians, hold great promise -- but only if the appropriate economic incentives are in place. The notion that a technology like Watson, if unbiased, is going to reduce health care spending significantly seems misguided. But such technologies can make a useful difference if the right economic incentives are in place.

headline.main: When Chronic Illness Interrupts the Rhythms of College

docs.abstract: Lily Altavena, a junior at New York University who suffers from Crohn's disease, shares her experiences dealing with a chronic illness at school and tips for other students with medical issues.
docs.snippet: Lily Altavena, a junior at New York University who suffers from Crohn's disease, shares her experiences dealing with a chronic illness at school and tips for other students with medical issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ms. Altavena, a junior majoring in journalism and urban studies at New York University, is an intern this semester on The New York Times Learning Network and The Choice.

headline.main: Raising the Price of Reproductive Rights

docs.abstract: State and local restrictions on abortion have made it harder for women, especially among the poor, to obtain abortions, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: A report says most New York medical centers are violating state rules curbing aggressive debt collections against people who cannot pay.

headline.seo: Study Finds New York Hospitals Flout Charity Rules

docs.abstract: Report finds most New York medical centers are violating state rules curbing aggressive debt collections against people who cannot pay; many states are wrestling with aggressive debt collection by hospitals and, like New York, have passed laws curbing hospitals' pursuit of unpaid bills; New York's charity care system, partly financed by an 8.95 percent surcharge on hospital bills, is one of nation's most complicated and some experts say entire system is corrupted.
docs.snippet: A report says most New York medical centers are violating state rules curbing aggressive debt collections against people who cannot pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Legislative Exchange Council is writing hundreds of destructive bills on a host of subjects dear to corporate and conservative interests.

headline.seo: The Big Money Behind State Laws
headline.main: The Big Money Behind State Laws
headline.print_headline: The Big Money Behind State Laws

docs.abstract: Editorial observes that the American Legislative Exchange Council, a little-known conservative organization financed by millions of corporate dollars, has written legislation on a variety of issues, which state Republican lawmakers across the country use as models for their own proposals; argues that while there is nothing illegal or unethical about ALEC's work, it further demonstrates the pervasive influence of corporate money and right-wing groups on the state legislative process.
docs.snippet: The American Legislative Exchange Council is writing hundreds of destructive bills on a host of subjects dear to corporate and conservative interests.

docs.lead_paragraph: As President Obama shifts more fully into campaign mode, he faces the increasingly difficult task of balancing his policy duties as president with his political imperatives as a candidate. The week ahead will test his ability to manage those two roles as the White House and his campaign advisers juggle fund-raising, legislative maneuvering and continuing controversy over health care and religious freedom.

headline.main: A Delicate Balance For the President

docs.abstract: Caucus column notes that as President Obama shifts more fully into campaign mode, he faces the increasingly difficult task of balancing his policy duties as president with his political imperatives as a candidate. Photos (M)p
